descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for Imperial Chemical Industries (India) Ltd., a painting of the popular Indian artist Ravi Varma can be seen depicting Vishnu on his mount, Garuda with his two consorts, Sridevi and Bhudevi. On the lower section of the image, a collage of pictures can be seen, probably part of the same advertisement series. The image is surrounded by a wooden frame.

inscription.text: Imperial Chemical Industries (India) Ltd. Ravi Varma Puladi Dhivram Konda, I.C.I. Distributiors TOB, South Masi ST. Madurai "Crescent House", Ballad Estate, Bombay Branches: Ahmedabad, Alleppey, Amritsar, Bombay, Calcutta, Delhi, Indore, Kanpur, Madras

description-en: On this advertisement for Imperial Chemical Industries (India) Ltd., a painting of the popular Indian artist Ravi Varma can be seen depicting Vishnu on his mount, Garuda with his two consorts, Sridevi and Bhudevi. On the lower section of the image, a collage of pictures can be seen, probably part of the same advertisement series. The image is surrounded by a wooden frame. (gs/ja/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) was a British chemical company, taken over by a number of chemical companies, including Huntsman Corporation, a United States-based company, and AkzoNobel, a Dutch conglomerate, two of the largest chemical producers in the world. In its heyday, ICI was the largest manufacturing company in the British Empire, and commonly regarded as a "bellwether of the British economy".[1] It produced paints and speciality products (including ingredients for foods, specialty polymers, electronic materials, fragrances and flavours). It employed around 29,000 people and had a turnover of just over Â£4.8 billion in 2006. The company was independent from 1926 to 2008, headquartered for most of that time in Millbank, London, and was a constituent of the FT30 Index and FTSE 100 Index. After the January 2008 change of ownership, AkzoNobel fully integrated ICI's operations within its existing organisation. (from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Chemical_Industries) ()(gs)
